choices.text: Continuous visual display of an ECG

questions.text: ASA mandates the use of all of the following monitors during general anaesthesia to encourage universal quality and safety practices except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

According to the ASA guidelines, it does not mandate the use of the peripheral nerve stimulator during general anaesthesia.

ASA standards mandate the use of:

  • Pulse oximetry(Option A ruled out).
  • capnography(Option B ruled out)
  • An oxygen analyser in the breathing system,
  • disconnect alarms,
  • a visual display of an ECG(Option C ruled out)
  • systemic blood pressure and heart rate monitoring and
  • temperature monitoring (when clinically indicated) for all cases.
  • Blood pressure through whatever form is deemed appropriate, and this must be checked at least every 5 minutes.

Reference: https://www.asahq.org/standards-and-guidelines/standards-for-basic-anesthetic-monitoring

questions.text: During a complicated cardiac case, the surgeon informs you that he is worried about damage to the right coronary artery in a patient with a right-dominant coronary system. During reperfusion, you are looking for signs of ischemia and are most interested in leads.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Ischemic changes in leads II, III and aVFsuggest right coronary artery disease. The inferior wall of the left ventricle is predominantly supplied by the RCA in a right-dominant coronary system.
  • V1-V3(Option A): Leads V1 to V3. These leads primarily monitor the septal and anterior walls of the heart, which are typically supplied by the left anterior descending artery. They are less relevant for detecting ischemia in the RCA territory.
  • V4-V6(Option B): V4-V6: These leads assess the anterior and lateral walls, supplied by the left anterior descending and circumflex arteries, respectively. They are not the primary leads for monitoring RCA-related ischemia.
  • I and aVL(Option D): leads I and aVL monitor the circumflex artery distribution. They may show reciprocal changes in the context of inferior wall ischemia, but are not the primary leads for detecting ischemia in the RCA territory.

questions.text: Pulse oximetry illuminates tissue samples with two wavelengths of light to calculate oxygen saturation. These wavelengths are of the following nm:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Oximetry depends on the observation that oxygenated and reduced haemoglobin differ in their absorption of red and infrared light according to Lambert-Beer law.
  • Specifically, oxyhemoglobin (HbO2) absorbs more infrared light (940nm),
  • Whereas deoxyhemoglobin absorbs more red light (660nm) and thus appears blue, or cyanotic, to the naked eye.

choices.text: Amplitude to decrease and latency to increase
Amplitude to increase and latency to decrease

questions.text: During cervical spine surgery for the resection of an intradural mass, the patient begins to cough. The concentration of isoflurane is subsequently increased. Concerning somatosensory-evoked potential (SSEP) monitoring, you would expect
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Indications for intraoperative monitoring of evoked potentials (EPs) include surgical procedures associated with possible neurological injury: spinal fusion with instrumentation, spine and spinal cord tumour resection, brachial plexus repair, thoracoabdominal aortic aneurysm repair, epilepsy surgery, and cerebral tumour resection.
  • Volatile agents such as isoflurane decrease the amplitude and increase the latency of evoked potentials. These changes are primarily due to the anaesthetist's inhibitory effects on synaptic transmission, which impact cortical EPs more significantly than subcortical or peripheral responses.
  • In the scenario where a patient undergoing cervical spine surgery begins to cough, an increase in isoflurane concentration is typically administered to deepen anaesthesia and suppress the cough reflex. This increase in isoflurane concentration would likely lead to a further decrease in EP amplitude and an increase in latency.

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman has had a laparoscopic salpingectomy for an ectopic pregnancy. She received a total of 50 mg of atracurium during the procedure. At the end of the operation, a nerve stimulator is used to assess the depth of neuromuscular blockade. Which of the following nerves best reflects the extent of neuromuscular blockade of the diaphragm?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • During reversal of a peripheral muscle, such as the adductor pollicis (via thumb) should be monitored which is supplied by the ulnar nerve.
  • As the peripheral muscles have a slower recovery time, the recovery of the peripheral muscles would indicate that the respiratory muscles have recovered to a greater degree. This provides a larger margin of safety.
  • Monitoring here is the standard and gold-standard reference for determining adequate reversal and predicting diaphragmatic recovery.
  • The diaphragm is more resistant to neuromuscular blockers than peripheral muscles, and both recover faster and respond differently.
  • The adductor pollicis (via ulnar nerve) is the standard site for Train-of-Four (TOF) monitoring-the cornerstone for assessing the depth of blockade and ensuring safe reversal thresholds, including a TOF ratio ≥ 0.9 before extubation.

choices.text: Medial head of sternocleidomastoid, trapezius and clavicle
Lateral head of sternocleidomastoid, trapezius and clavicle
Medial and lateral heads of sternocleidomastoid and clavicle

questions.text: While cannulating the internal jugular vein in a patient, you look for a triangle that is formed by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The two heads of the sternocleidomastoid muscle and the clavicle form the three sides of a triangle, under the apex of which, the internal jugular vein can be cannulated, also known as Seldinger's technique.
  • Cannulation carries potential complications such as bleeding, pneumothorax, air embolism and injury to surrounding structures.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman undergoing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy has an oxygen saturation that rapidly decreases to 80% on 100% inspired oxygen, peak airway pressures increase to 38 cmH2O, and blood pressure reduces to 72/42 mmHg. Examination demonstrates absent breath sounds and a hyper-resonant percussion note on the left side of the chest. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This patient is ;demonstrating clinical features of a tension pneumothorax with hypoxia, elevated airway pressures and hypotension.
  • Tension pneumothorax, a potentially life-threatening condition, can occur during laparoscopic surgery due to the insufflation of carbon dioxide into the abdominal cavity, which can escape into the pleural cavity.
  • This is a recognised risk of laparoscopic surgery and requires immediate recognition and treatment with insertion of a cannula in the second intercostal space, midclavicular line on the affected side.An intercostal chest drain should then be inserted for this life-threatening emergency.
  • (B) and (C) Optimising ventilator parameters would not treat the cause and may worsen any tension by increasing the size of the pneumothorax.
  • Fluid Bolus(Option D): Administration of intravenous fluid boluses would be of benefit, but would not address the underlying cause.

questions.text: You are inserting a pulmonary artery catheter in a patient. The pressure waveform while floating reads 24/14 mmHg. What is the most likely location of the catheter tip?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image given below shows the characteristic waveforms recorded during the passage of the pulmonary artery catheter.

The pressures seen in the waveforms include:

  • Right atrium: 0-5 mmHg (Option A ruled out)
  • Right ventricle: 20-25/0-5 mmHg (Option B ruled out)
  • Pulmonary artery: 20-25/10-15 mmHg
  • Pulmonary artery wedge pressure: 6-12 mmHg (end expiratory) (Option C ruled out)

Thus, a pressure of 24/14 probably corresponds with pulmonary arterial pressure.

choices.text: Administer muscle relaxant to the patient

questions.text: You have applied the following monitor to a patient undergoing cardiac surgery. Intraoperatively, the monitor shows the value given in the image as 91. What will be your next step in management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given image is of bi-spectral index monitoring (BIS monitoring), which is used to monitor the depth of anaesthesia in indicated surgeries.

  • A value of 100 corresponds to being completely awake, whereas 0 corresponds to a profound state of coma or unconsciousness that is reflected by an isoelectric or flat EEG.
  • A patient is considered to beappropriately anesthetist (i.e., unconscious) when the value of the BIS is between 40 and 60.
  • 0-20 represents a very deep hypnotic state, or coma.
  • 70-80 represents moderate sedation.
  • 80-90 represents light sedation.
  • 90-100 represents a fully awake state.

Here, the 91 value is given, which indicates a requirement to deepen the plane of anaesthesia to decrease the value from 91 to 60 and below. Hence, the answer is option b.

Reference:

Miller's Anesthesiology, 8th edition, pg 1282

questions.text: While monitoring a patient for return of neuromuscular function after using rocuronium, you notice the patient has regained four twitches using train-of-four simulations. With four twitches on a train of four simulations, the patient may still have blockage of acetylcholine receptors of up to
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • At the point the fourth twitch reappears, up to 75% to 80% of acetylcholine receptors may still be blocked. Meaning that 25% of the receptors have recovered.
  • Adequate reversal (neostigmine-glycopyrrolate) should be given, and clinical signs for return of neuromuscular function should be used to gauge readiness for extubation.

choices.text: Increasing the duration of action of muscle relaxants

questions.text: 4 hours into a laparotomy surgery, the temperature probe reads a measurement of 28 degrees Celsius. Detrimental effects of hypothermia include all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cerebral oxygen consumption decreases by approximately 7% per degree Celsius decrease in temperature. Hence, the given statement is false, as the oxygen consumption decreases due to a decrease in temperature.

Hypothermia is associated with:

  • Delayed drug metabolism,
  • Increased blood glucose
  • Vasoconstriction
  • Increased risk of surgical site infections (Option B ruled out).
  • Impaired coagulation (Option C ruled out)
  • postoperative shivering accompanied by tachycardia and hypertension, and
  • Increased risk of surgical site infections (Option D ruled out)

questions.text: Match the following frequency bands in the EEG to the psychological state
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • EEG is a test that measures brain activity using electrodes placed on the scalp.
  • It records electrical impulses generated by neurons, which show up as wavy lines on the EEG recording.
  • The EEG is a varying voltage signal, with amplitudes between 1 and 500 μV.
  • For interpretation, the frequency spectrum is divided into five bands.

questions.text: Which of the following measures of awareness under anaesthesia is depicted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The bispectral index (BIS versions 3.0 and higher) is a dimensionless scale from 0 (complete cortical electroencephalographic suppression) to 100 (awake).
  • BIS values of 65-85 have been recommended for sedation, whereas values of 40-65 have been recommended for general anaesthesia.

Patient state index(Option A): The patient state index (PSI) is derived from a four-channel electroencephalograph. The PSI has a range of 0-100, with decreasing values indicating lower levels of consciousness and sedation.

Narcotrend(Option B): The Narcotrend is derived from a system developed for the visual classification of the EEG patterns associated with various stages of sleep. The original electronic algorithm classified the frontal EEG according to: A (awake), B (sedated), C (light anaesthesia), D (general anaesthesia), E(general anaesthesia with deep hypnosis), F (general anaesthesia with increasing burst suppression).

Entropy (Option C): This describes the irregularity, complexity or unpredictability characteristics of a signal. A single sine wave represents a completely predictable signal (entropy), whereas noise from a random number generator represents entropy =1.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC2900098/

questions.text: A patient with methemoglobinemia will have a pulse oximetry reading that converges around a saturation of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Many different clinical situations will cause pulse oximetry to read in characteristic patterns.

  • Oximetry depends on the observation that oxygenated and reduced haemoglobin differ in their absorption of red and infrared light according to Lambert-Beer law.
  • Oxyhemoglobin (HbO2) absorbs more infrared light (940nm).
  • Whereas deoxyhemoglobin absorbs more red light (660nm) and thus appears blue, or cyanotic, to the naked eye.
  • Methemoglobinemia absorbs both wavelengths of light and tends to converge around a saturation of 85%
  • Carboxyhemoglobin only absorbs red light, but not infrared light, and can vary widely in saturation readings.
  • Methylene blue, a common dye used during surgery, tends to cause saturations to converge around 65%.
